text: Good afternoon.

Beloved friends, family,
partners, administrators,

faculty, distinguished guests,
Dean Srikant Datar, Professors

Matt Weinzierl, Mitch
Weiss, and Suraj Srinivasan,

and, of course, Harvard Business
School's MBA Class of 2024.
Woo!
Welcome to Class Day.
My name is Tricia Peralta.
I'm a proud Filipino.

And I'm an even prouder
President of the best section
ever, Section I. Where you at?

I am also the Student
Association's Co-Chief Community

Officer and Class Day Co-Chair,
together with Matthew Robert
Glynn and Katie Kondry.

Class day is an HBS tradition
that dates back to 1996.

This occasion provides
us with a moment

to reflect on our last two years
and consider the difference we
want to make in this world.

This is a celebration
just for us at HBS.

Tomorrow, we join
the rest of Harvard

to listen to the words of my
fellow Filipina, Maria Ressa.
Then we receive our diplomas.

And before we know it, be on
our way back to the real world.

But first, we want
to acknowledge
what it took to get us here.

Let's take a moment to pause
and consider Harvard's history.

Harvard University is situated
upon the traditional land
of the Massachusett tribe.

We acknowledge the painful
history of genocide

and forced removal
from this territory,

and we honor and respect
the many Indigenous peoples
still connected to this place.

We also recognize
the ongoing work
required to restore this land.

We also honor the memory of
the more than 70 individuals

enslaved by Harvard University
leaders, faculty, and staff
between 1636 and 1783.

We also recognize all
the enslaved men, women,

and children whose
labor generated

wealth that helped create the
Harvard that we know today.

We also acknowledge that
as Harvard Business School,

we too need to learn our
own history and context

and continue
exploring our school's
entanglement with slavery.

We know that much
pain and suffering was

part of our
institution's history,

and we carry that
weight with us today.

Similarly, we
acknowledge the impact

of the events that occurred
while we sat in Aldrich Hall
over the last two years.

Much of the world
continued to change, some

for the better,
some for the worse.

ChatGPT made reading our
cases so much easier.

But the job market
proved more challenging

than we would have
anticipated, with many

of us feeling like we're still
choosing only the next best
thing.

While we learned how
to be more inclusive

and how to sit and listen to
diverse viewpoints in case

discussions, the
world we re-enter

is even more divided
and unwelcoming
than when we first arrived.

The widespread
loss of human life

due to international
conflict has impacted so many

within the Harvard
community, and we

will continue to mourn those
losses for the years to come.

But as I look around
at my fellow graduates,

I continue to feel
excited and hopeful.

The people I met over
the last two years

have challenged and inspired
me with their stories,
their dreams, and their hearts.

I have no doubt that
each and every one of us

feels similarly shaped by the
people we surrounded ourselves
with.

The next hour will go by like a
blur, especially in this heat.

But I challenge you all to
try and be fully present

and use this as an opportunity
to actively listen and reflect
on the last two years.

As we move on into
the real world,

I hope the lessons that
we take from this place

will help us be better
leaders and human beings.
